episode.content: Uniquease, a restaurant in a disadvantaged area of Manila, has employed over 70 troubled youths and taught them to cook and serve. Founded in 2010 by Nakamura Yachiyo, business at the restaurant had been growing steadily until the novel coronavirus pandemic, which forced Nakamura to downsize to focus on takeout and delivery. We first visited Nakamura in 2016. 4 years later, she and her staff are battling the turbulent winds of a pandemic on their quest to break the chains of poverty.
episode.description: A restaurant in Manila hires disadvantaged youth, guiding them to independence. But COVID-19 has forced founder Nakamura Yachiyo to downsize operations, and she's come to a painful decision.
episode.subtitle: Conquering COVID-19: A Painful Decision - The Philippines

episode.content: Taya Toru runs a farm in Fukui Prefecture, in central Japan. 6 young people from Indonesia work there as technical interns, acquiring skills and laying the foundations for their future dreams. But they're learning more than Japanese farming techniques. Taya was a youth volunteer in Indonesia's farming villages and studied rural sociology at Indonesia's agricultural university. He wants his trainees to return home and become local leaders. Alongside the farm work he's also helping them draw up business plans that draw on their earnings during their 3 years in Japan. Meet the young Indonesians planning for the future as they work, and the man ensuring their efforts will bear fruit.
episode.description: Six young interns from Indonesia work on Taya Toru's farm in Fukui Pref,. Taya's own history means he's dedicated to helping them write business plans for their return and build dreams for the future.
episode.subtitle: Fostering Indonesian Farming Entrepreneurial Skills: Fukui, Japan
